Option C is the only one where all elements are correctly reflected. Option A is a 180-degree rotation. Option B reflects most parts correctly but fails to move the circle to its reflected position. explanation: To find the correct reflection, every part of the original figure must be mirrored across a vertical axis. The original figure has a circle in the top-right, a triangle on the left pointing out, and a diagonal line from top-left to bottom-right. 1. The circle moves from the top-right to the top-left. 2. The triangle moves from the left side to the right side, and its orientation is flipped so it still points outwards. 3. The diagonal line's endpoints are flipped horizontally, so it now runs from top-right to bottom-left. Option C is the only figure that correctly reflects all three elements. Option A has the wrong diagonal line. Option B is a 180-degree rotation. Option D shows the triangle pointing inwards, which is an incorrect reflection. Option E fails to reflect the position of the triangle.

explanation: The question asks to identify the correct reflection. The figure on the left consists of three parts: a large L-shape, a small circle in its base, and a triangle to its right. A reflection across the vertical line flips the figure horizontally. The L-shape becomes a backwards L-shape on the right. The triangle moves from the right of the L-shape to the left of the reflected L-shape. The circle moves from the left side of the L-shape's base to the right side of the reflected L-shape's base. Only option C shows all three elements correctly reflected. Option A is a 180-degree rotation. Option B is a partial reflection where the circle is not reflected. Option D shows the circle in the wrong position within the reflected L-shape. Option E shows a vertical flip of the original figure.

explanation: To find the mirror image of figure C across a vertical line, each component must be flipped horizontally. The main L-shaped outline is flipped. The small circle moves from the bottom-left to the bottom-right. The small triangle that points right in figure C must point left in its reflection. Figure E is the only option where all three components are correctly reflected. Option A is a 180-degree rotation of C. Option B is a partial reflection where the triangle has not been flipped. Option D is a reflection across a horizontal line, not a vertical one.

explanation: The correct option is the one where the figure on the right is a perfect mirror image of the figure on the left across the vertical dashed line. Option C is the only one that shows a correct reflection. In option A, the right figure is a 180-degree rotation. In option B, the right figure is a translation (a copy shifted to the right). In option D, the main triangle is reflected correctly, but the internal white circle is misplaced. In option E, the individual components are reflected, but their vertical positions are swapped.
